cluster_relations.rel_desc: The strike by pyramid workers is an instance of a strike.
cluster_relations.subject_class_label: Pyramid Construction and Labor Strike (Ancient Egypt)

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: HistoricalStatus: one of the earliest recorded protests

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Violent uprisings are a type of revolutionary or uprising event.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Context: discussed in relation to protests and revolutions

remarks: Some reliance on domain knowledge; relation included for coverage with moderate confidence.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: The Arab Spring is a specific set of protests and revolutions.
remarks: More generic conceptual mapping; created to connect Arab Spring to general protest phenomena.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Protests and revolutions are mentioned together as types of contentious actions.
remarks: Relation used to capture their joint treatment as targets of repression.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Public protest demonstrations are mentioned together with revolutions as related forms of collective action.
remarks: Association is conceptual rather than a specific causal claim.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Connects a specific event or case to the more general class or category it instantiates.
args.justification: Both relations link a concrete, specific event (strike by pyramid workers; Arab Spring) to a broader category of events (strikes; protests and revolutions). This is a standard instance-to-class relation, so they should share the canonical predicate is_instance_of.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Connects a more specific subclass or subtype to a more general class within a taxonomy or classification.
args.justification: The relation states that violent uprisings are a type of revolutionary or uprising event, which is a class-to-class hierarchical relation. This is better modeled as a subtype relation than an instance relation, so use is_subtype_of.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two concepts or entities are treated together as parallel or related items without implying hierarchy or causality.
args.justification: Both relations describe protests and revolutions being mentioned together as parallel or related forms of contention, with logical markers like 'and' and hints of co-occurrence/association. They are symmetric, non-hierarchical links, so a single predicate grouped_with is appropriate.

All three links are part of a taxonomic or ontological hierarchy: two are instance-to-class and one is subtype-to-class. Grouping them under a shared class taxonomic_hierarchy_relation captures that they all express membership or subsumption in a conceptual taxonomy.

These relations express that protests and revolutions are discussed together as related or parallel phenomena without specifying hierarchy or causality. This fits a broader family of conceptual/associative links, hence conceptual_association_relation.

Instance-of and subtype relations are forms of identity/typing links between particular or specific categories and their superordinate types. They belong under a broad identity/typing dimension rather than causality or association.
These edges simply indicate that protests and revolutions co-occur conceptually and are treated together, which is a non-causal associative relation. This aligns with the ASSOCIATION group.
